choices.A: For the Finance OU, enable the third-party app in SAML apps.
choices.B: For the Finance OU, enable the third-party app in Marketplace Apps.
choices.D: At the root level, disable the third-party app. For the Finance OU, allow users to install only whitelisted apps from the G Suite Marketplace.
choices.C: At the root level, disable the third-party app. For the Finance OU, allow users to install any application from the G Suite Marketplace.

questions.question_text:
Your company recently migrated to G Suite and wants to deploy a commonly used third-party app to all of finance. Your OU structure in G Suite is broken down by department. You need to ensure that the correct users get this app.
What should you do?

discussion.content:
(B) - Add to Domain List and choose only Finance OU
Tested we can't restrict "whitelisted app" per OU, whitelisted app is available domain-wide

comments.content: nwk was saying that we can't restrict "installing" whitelisted app per OU, and what mark gave is Turn on or off the service. vote for B
according to this link [https://support.google.com/a/answer/172931?hl=en] you CAN restrict whitelisted apps at a OU level, making D the correct answer

discussion.content: I will go with Option B because D says just about marketplace apps and whitelisting but doesn't say if third party app will be enabled for them.,

Selected Answer: B
You want to DEPLOY so you need to install it for the OU from Marketplace Apps.
Whitelisting will allow users to use it but will not deploy it.
B is correct
B and E
What would be the correct answer?
What about B? - doesn't say disable for other users and is a commonly used app
I would go for D.

I think its C. "The sales team is often a target of mass email from legitimate senders, which is distracting to their job duties" and "Constant Contact is often used as the source of these messages".

Nowhere in the question did it specify that emails received via Constant Contact should be allowed for the sales OU. It only mentioned that the company uses Constant Contact for its own outgoing emails- which in this case does not affect the answer at all.

Selected Answer: C
It should be C

By passing blocked settings for Constant Contact emails, will still allow mails sent from bulk sender constant contact with a new email address to reach the sales team. Simply blocking the sender email address will still allow internal constant contact mail reach the sales team.
instead in other online sites I have seen that all give the correct answer to A.
Hello, could someone confirm the correct answer please. Thank you

Selected Answer: C
correct answer is C

Selected Answer: C
The Sales OU doesn't need the bypass

Selected Answer: C
Why should we bypass the setting for Constant Contact emails ?
Only Sales need to be preserve for inbound mass emailing. This rule will not interfer with their external mass mailing system.
A - letting the Constant Contact emails, e.g., emails with @constantcontact.com, through will ensure you can still use the service for mass outgoing emails
A is correct

I think it's C, too. A blocked senders list containing an exception for Constant Contact would let the very emails you're trying to block right through. You can set up a block rule that doesn't affect outgoing messages.
Hello, could someone confirm the correct answer please. Thank you
I will go with Option A, you dont want to block those contant contact where you have potential to sell in future,
So finally it is A? you can just block for sales OU and create an exception for the specific group.? I think it is the most accurate solution.
I would go for A.
Vote for C, 2 different OU, Sales OU setting does not affect Marketing OU

choices.B: Create a blocked senders list at the root level, and then an approved senders list at the Market Research OU, both containing the mass email sender addresses.
choices.C: Create a blocked senders list at the Sales OU that contains the mass email sender addresses.
choices.A: Create a blocked senders list as the Sales OU that contains the mass email sender addresses, but bypass this setting for Constant Contact emails.
choices.D: Create an approved senders list at the Market Research OU that contains the mass email sender addresses.

questions.question_text:
Your company has an OU that contains your sales team and an OU that contains your market research team. The sales team is often a target of mass email from legitimate senders, which is distracting to their job duties. The market research team also receives that email content, but they want it because it often contains interesting market analysis or competitive intelligence. Constant Contact is often used as the source of these messages. Your company also uses Constant
Contact for your own mass email marketing. You need to set email controls at the Sales OU without affecting your own outgoing email or the market research OU.
What should you do?

choices.A: Obtain the message header and analyze using G Suite Toolbox.
choices.C: Set up a Gmail routing rule to whitelist the sender.
choices.D: Conduct an Email log search to trace the message route.
choices.E: Validate that your domain is not on the Spamhaus blacklist.
choices.B: Review the contents of the messages in Google Vault.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
A will help to determine why the message is considered as Spam. 
and maybe C : it will prevent the sender to be considered as Spam again but it is not troubleshooting, it is solving the issue without knowing why it happens.

B will allow to access all the email content, not only the header but you are not a human spam detector. D. Email log search will only tell you "Spam detected", no more information than with A. E is useless since it is an inbound issue.
The task is troubleshooting the issue, so you need to do actions in A and D. C is already a solution, and not an appropriate one since you can just add the sender to the Approved senders list.

I don't think "A" is the right option as I check my own spam email in this Google workspace Toolbox.
You can also check your own spam email and check from this link
https://toolbox.googleapps.com/apps/messageheader/

So my answer is 

C and D
C+D is the best option
A+C is correct
The best options would be A and C
I will also go with A and C here.
A and C is the correct answer.
i think the answer is B and C

questions.question_text:
The CEO of your company has indicated that messages from trusted contacts are being delivered to spam, and it is significantly affecting their work. The messages from these contacts have not always been classified as spam. Additionally, you recently configured SPF, DKIM, and DMARC for your domain. You have been tasked with troubleshooting the issue.
What two actions should you take? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
correct answer is D
D is correct
Option D, would be the correct answer?
D is correct option here, A cant be because its just log console activity, B successful and failed sign-ins to SAML applications using the SAML audit log, C is just for drive.
https://support.google.com/a/answer/6124308?hl=en

questions.question_text:
Security and Compliance has identified that data is being leaked through a third-party application connected to G SuiteÑŽ You want to investigate using an audit log.
What log should you use?

choices.C: Deploy browser or device certificates via G Suite.
choices.A: Enable additional security verification via email.
choices.B: Enable authentication via the Google Authenticator.
choices.D: Configure USB Yubikeys for all users.

discussion.content: Because they have blocked peripheral access to devices (a.k.a. they have disabled USB access so the device keys won't work)

Selected Answer: B
Enable authentication via the Google Authenticator is the only secure option since USB device aren't usable. Google Authenticator is the most secure option after physical key.
B is correct
Would the answer be option B?
Can someone please explain how google authenticator is the correct answer?

comments.content: Even though Physical Keys are best practices, the option that is enabled on their environment does not allow them to use them. Blocked Peripheral access means no Yubikeys since USB ports are assumed disabled.

questions.question_text:
Your company wants to provide secure access for its employees. The Chief Information Security Officer disabled peripheral access to devices, but wants to enable 2-Step verification. You need to provide secure access to the applications using G Suite.
What should you do?
